text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: In a classroom of 25 students, each student is assigned a number from 1 to 20 (inclusive).
Prove that there must be at least two students who are assigned the same number.

Solution: 
<think>
Alright, so I've got this problem here: In a classroom of 25 students, each student is assigned a number from 1 to 20.
I need to prove that there must be at least two students who have the same number.
Hmm, okay, let me think through this step by step.
First off, I remember something about the pigeonhole principle from my math classes.
I think that's the idea where if you have more items than containers, at least one container must hold more than one item.
Maybe that applies here.
Let me try to recall exactly how that works.

So, the pigeonhole principle, if I remember correctly, states that if you have 'n' items and 'm' containers, where 'n' is greater than 'm', then at least one container must contain more than one item.
That seems relevant here because we have more students than numbers available.
In this problem, there are 25 students and numbers from 1 to 20.
So, the numbers are the containers, and the students are the items.
Each student is assigned a number, which is like placing an item into a container.
If there are more students than there are numbers, then by the pigeonhole principle, at least one number must be assigned to more than one student.
Let me write this down to visualize it better.
The number of students is 25, and the number of unique numbers we can assign is 20.
So, 25 students trying to fit into 20 numbers.
If we try to assign each student a unique number, the 20th student would have to take a number that's already been taken by one of the previous students.
That means two students would end up sharing the same number.
Wait, but maybe I should think of it more formally.
Let's consider each number from 1 to 20 as a "hole" and each student as an "object" or "item" that goes into a hole.
If I have 20 holes and 25 objects, then when I start placing the objects into the holes, the first 20 objects can each go into their own hole.
But the 21st object has nowhere else to go except into one of the existing holes.

That means the 21st object will cause a collision, right?

So, in this case, since there are 25 students and only 20 numbers, after placing 20 students each with unique numbers, the 21st student has to go into one of the existing numbers.
Therefore, there must be at least two students sharing a number.
That makes sense.
Let me double-check if I'm applying the principle correctly.

The pigeonhole principle formula is usually stated as:

If n items are put into m containers, with n > m, then at least one container must contain more than one item.
Here, n is 25 (students) and m is 20 (numbers).
Since 25 > 20, the condition is satisfied, so the conclusion holds.
Therefore, there must be at least one number that's assigned to two students.
I think that's solid.

Is there any way around this? Could the numbers be assigned in a way that avoids duplication? Well, if you have only 20 unique numbers, the maximum number of students you can have without duplication is 20.
Once you have 21, you must have a repeat.
So, 25 is definitely more than 20, which forces duplication.
Wait, just to make sure, let's imagine assigning numbers one by one.
Student 1 gets 1, student 2 gets 2, and so on up to student 20, each getting a unique number.
Then student 21 has to go to a number that's already taken, say number 1.
Then student 22 goes to another number, maybe 2, but then someone else has to share a number again, and so on until student 25.
So, in this process, every time after the 20th student, each subsequent student causes a collision, meaning at least one number is shared by two students.
Yeah, that seems to hold up.
I can't think of a way to assign 25 unique numbers from 1 to 20 because there aren't enough unique numbers.
It's like trying to fit 25 pigeons into 20 holes—no matter how you arrange them, at least one hole will have more than one pigeon.
So, putting it all together, by the pigeonhole principle, since the number of students (25) exceeds the number of available numbers (20), there must be at least two students assigned the same number.

</think>

By the pigeonhole principle, since there are 25 students and only 20 unique numbers available, at least two students must share the same number.
Therefore, it is proven that there must be at least two students with the same assigned number.
